title: Practically-A-Book Review: EA Hotel
summary:
Key ideas:
- Effective altruism focuses on redirecting charity resources to the most important and successful charities
- San Francisco is an expensive city, making it difficult for smaller independent organizations to conduct research
- Greg Colbourn, an effective altruist and cryptocurrency investor, purchased a 17-bedroom hotel in Blackpool, northern England to offer free room and board to researchers working on effective altruist projects
- By living at the hotel, researchers can focus on their work without worrying about material needs
- The hotel can support people for £5700/year

Key learnings:
- The hotel project is a potential high impact, high prestige supporting role for those excited to be involved in such a capacity on an EA mission
- Living at the hotel is more cost-effective than giving people grants that allow researchers to support themselves
- Community building is becoming increasingly important to the further development of the EA movement
- The hotel provides a low-barrier-to-entry opportunity for researchers to work on effective altruist ideas

Key questions:
- Is the hotel project more effective than just spending the money on grants?
- How will the hotel ensure that guests are effective and productive researchers?
- What measures will the hotel have in place to prevent scammers and freeloaders?
- Will living at the hotel lead to increased focus, collaboration, and morale boosting productivity?
